results.title: Ulster heritage
results.creator_credit: R.H.R. Productions, Film Producers Guild, Ronald H. Riley and Stanley Willis
results.brief_description: From the story of one family and one farm in Northern Ireland, a colorful and impressive picture of a modern farming community emerges, giving incidental glimpses of Ulster as a highly modern industrialised province and a place of considerable scenic attractions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: R.H.R. Productions, Film Producers Guild, Ronald H. Riley and Stanley Willis

results.title: Ulster
results.brief_description: Shows some of the scenic and sporting attractions of Northern Ireland and records, in particular, sequences from recent Tourist Trophy motor and Grand Prix motor-cycle events (featuring Stirling Moss). The film includes a visit to Belfast, capital of Northern Ireland; scenic attractions among the mountain and lake country; a visit to Carlingford Lough and the Silent Valley; a drive through the Glen of Antrim to Portrush, famous for its swimming, sailing and its golf course.

results.title: Ulcer at work
results.creator_credit: University of Oklahoma and Ned Hockman
results.brief_description: Looks at the way in which emotional problems can cause ulcers, and illustrates the prescribed mental attitudes and dietary procedures necessary for curing a peptic ulcer in its preliminary stage.

results.title: Ukrainian dance
results.brief_description: Music and dances are performed by the Ukrainian Canadians of Manitoba, largest Slavonic group in Canada. The first part of the film shows the customs and religious ceremonies at holidays for these people. Four dances comprise the second part of the film: the Bird Dance, the Cossack Dance, the Cossack War Dance, and the Catherina Dance.

results.title: UK Prime Minister in Africa
results.brief_description: Scenes from Mr Harold MacMillan’s tour of Africa in the spring of 1960. Accompanied by Lady Dorothy MacMillan, the Prime Minister visits Ghana, Nigeria and the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, witnessing both the spectacular material progress in these quickly developing territories and the friendliness and goodwill which have not been affected by the achievement of the prospect of independence.

results.title: Ugetsu Monogatari [Extract]
results.creator_credit: Daiei Motion Picture Company and Contemporary Films
results.brief_description: An extract from what is considered to be a masterpiece of Japanese director, Kenji Mizoguchi. Set in sixteenth century Japan, its theme is that of the humble commoner who aspires to wealth and glory only to find them, when achieved, a delusion leading to agony and shame. In Japanese with English subtitles. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Uf-oh
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, John Bird and Glenn Melenhorst
results.brief_description: Adrian (voice by Egan Gill) is quietly working on his computer, but his trusty companion, a bandicoot named Openhiemer (voice by Paul Gherig), has other plans. Openheimer meddles with the computers and taps into some alien life, causing all sorts of mischief.

results.title: Udaipur, city of lakes
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, Ezra Mir and P.R.S. Pillay
results.brief_description: This beautiful lakeside city of India attracts tourists from all over the world. Udaipur is a city of palaces, surrounded by hills and lakes essential for irrigation which also enhance the landscape. Wonderful gardens, temples decorated with carved marble and a tower of victory built in the 15th century are examples of the beauty of this city. These religious people love festivals; with a boat procession on the lake and girls wearing colorful saris.

results.title: Ubu Roi Ou les Polonais
results.brief_description:
Alfred Jarry’s Ubu roi (‘King Ubu’) was produced in 1896, with nonrealistic settings and costumes. All the scene settings were displayed simultaneously on a backdrop, and the costumes and makeup were deliberately grotesque, as was the acting style, an amalgam of buffoonery, the horror of Grand Guignol, and extravagant mock-tragedy. Far from posing an alternative to the materialist values of the bourgeois audience, the first line of Ubu roi attacked the audience’s values head on. When Firmin Gemier, in the title role, advanced to face the audience, looked directly into their eyes, and uttered the first scandalous word of the text, ‘merde’ (‘excrement’), a pattern was set that has been followed by many avant-garde theatre companies throughout the 20th century. Reference: Encyclopedia Britanica Online. http://members.eb.com/bol/topic?eu=118827&sctn=3. Accessed January 3 2000

Credits: Director, Jean-Christophe Averty ; photography, Lucien Billard ; music, Claude Terrasse.
Cast: Jean Bouise, Rosy Varte, Hubert Deschamps, Henri Virlojeux.
